segment.source: Lets the user set a value in a given range.
segment.target: Lets the user set a value in a given range.

segment.source: Sliders
segment.target: Sliders

segment.source: Sliders
segment.target: Sliders

segment.source: A slider is a control that lets the user select from a range of values by moving a thumb control along a track.
segment.target: A slider is a control that lets the user select from a range of values by moving a thumb control along a track.

segment.source: A slider control
segment.target: A slider control

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Slider class
segment.target: Slider class

segment.source: Value property
segment.target: Value property

segment.source: ValueChanged event
segment.target: ValueChanged event

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Use a slider when you want your users to be able to set defined, contiguous values (such as volume or brightness) or a range of discrete values (such as screen resolution settings).
segment.target: Use a slider when you want your users to be able to set defined, contiguous values (such as volume or brightness) or a range of discrete values (such as screen resolution settings).

segment.source: A slider is a good choice when you know that users think of the value as a relative quantity, not a numeric value.
segment.target: A slider is a good choice when you know that users think of the value as a relative quantity, not a numeric value.

segment.source: For example, users think about setting their audio volume to low or medium—not about setting the value to 2 or 5.
segment.target: For example, users think about setting their audio volume to low or medium—not about setting the value to 2 or 5.

segment.source: Don't use a slider for binary settings.
segment.target: Don't use a slider for binary settings.

segment.source: Use a toggle switch instead.
segment.target: Use a toggle switch instead.

segment.source: Here are some additional factors to consider when deciding whether to use a slider:
segment.target: Here are some additional factors to consider when deciding whether to use a slider:

segment.source: Does the setting seem like a relative quantity?
segment.target: Does the setting seem like a relative quantity?

segment.source: If not, use radio buttons or a list box.
segment.target: If not, use radio buttons or a list box.

segment.source: Is the setting an exact, known numeric value?
segment.target: Is the setting an exact, known numeric value?

segment.source: If so, use a numeric text box.
segment.target: If so, use a numeric text box.

segment.source: Would a user benefit from instant feedback on the effect of setting changes?
segment.target: Would a user benefit from instant feedback on the effect of setting changes?

segment.source: If so, use a slider.
segment.target: If so, use a slider.

segment.source: For example, users can choose a color more easily by immediately seeing the effect of changes to hue, saturation, or luminosity values.
segment.target: For example, users can choose a color more easily by immediately seeing the effect of changes to hue, saturation, or luminosity values.

segment.source: Does the setting have a range of four or more values?
segment.target: Does the setting have a range of four or more values?

segment.source: If not, use radio buttons.
segment.target: If not, use radio buttons.

segment.source: Can the user change the value?
segment.target: Can the user change the value?

segment.source: Sliders are for user interaction.
segment.target: Sliders are for user interaction.

segment.source: If a user can't ever change the value, use read-only text instead.
segment.target: If a user can't ever change the value, use read-only text instead.

segment.source: If you are deciding between a slider and a numeric text box, use a numeric text box if:
segment.target: If you are deciding between a slider and a numeric text box, use a numeric text box if:

segment.source: Screen space is tight.
segment.target: Screen space is tight.

segment.source: The user is likely to prefer using the keyboard.
segment.target: The user is likely to prefer using the keyboard.

segment.source: Use a slider if:
segment.target: Use a slider if:

segment.source: Users will benefit from instant feedback.
segment.target: Users will benefit from instant feedback.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: A slider to control the volume on Windows Phone.
segment.target: A slider to control the volume on Windows Phone.

segment.source: A slider to control the volume on Windows Phone
segment.target: A slider to control the volume on Windows Phone

segment.source: A slider to change text size in Windows display settings.
segment.target: A slider to change text size in Windows display settings.

segment.source: A slider to change text size in Windows display settings
segment.target: A slider to change text size in Windows display settings

segment.source: Create a slider
segment.target: Create a slider

segment.source: Here's how to create a slider in XAML.
segment.target: Here's how to create a slider in XAML.

segment.source: Here's how to create a slider in code.
segment.target: Here's how to create a slider in code.

segment.source: You get and set the value of the slider from the Value property.
segment.target: You get and set the value of the slider from the Value property.

segment.source: To respond to value changes, you can use data binding to bind to the Value property, or handle the ValueChanged event.
segment.target: To respond to value changes, you can use data binding to bind to the Value property, or handle the ValueChanged event.

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Size the control so that users can easily set the value they want.
segment.target: Size the control so that users can easily set the value they want.

segment.source: For settings with discrete values, make sure the user can easily select any value using the mouse.
segment.target: For settings with discrete values, make sure the user can easily select any value using the mouse.

segment.source: Make sure the endpoints of the slider always fit within the bounds of a view.
segment.target: Make sure the endpoints of the slider always fit within the bounds of a view.

segment.source: Give immediate feedback while or after a user makes a selection (when practical).
segment.target: Give immediate feedback while or after a user makes a selection (when practical).

segment.source: For example, the Windows volume control beeps to indicate the selected audio volume.
segment.target: For example, the Windows volume control beeps to indicate the selected audio volume.

segment.source: Use labels to show the range of values.
segment.target: Use labels to show the range of values.

segment.source: Exception: If the slider is vertically oriented and the top label is Maximum, High, More, or equivalent, you can omit the other labels because the meaning is clear.
segment.target: Exception: If the slider is vertically oriented and the top label is Maximum, High, More, or equivalent, you can omit the other labels because the meaning is clear.

segment.source: Disable all associated labels or feedback visuals when you disable the slider.
segment.target: Disable all associated labels or feedback visuals when you disable the slider.

segment.source: Consider the direction of text when setting the flow direction and/or orientation of your slider.
segment.target: Consider the direction of text when setting the flow direction and/or orientation of your slider.

segment.source: Script flows from left to right in some languages, and from right to left in others.
segment.target: Script flows from left to right in some languages, and from right to left in others.

segment.source: Don't use a slider as a progress indicator.
segment.target: Don't use a slider as a progress indicator.

segment.source: Don't change the size of the slider thumb from the default size.
segment.target: Don't change the size of the slider thumb from the default size.

segment.source: Don't create a continuous slider if the range of values is large and users will most likely select one of several representative values from the range.
segment.target: Don't create a continuous slider if the range of values is large and users will most likely select one of several representative values from the range.

segment.source: Instead, use those values as the only steps allowed.
segment.target: Instead, use those values as the only steps allowed.

segment.source: For example if time value might be up to 1 month but users only need to pick from 1 minute, 1 hour, 1 day or 1 month, then create a slider with only 4 step points.
segment.target: For example if time value might be up to 1 month but users only need to pick from 1 minute, 1 hour, 1 day or 1 month, then create a slider with only 4 step points.

segment.source: Additional usage guidance
segment.target: Additional usage guidance

segment.source: Choosing the right layout: horizontal or vertical
segment.target: Choosing the right layout: horizontal or vertical

segment.source: You can orient your slider horizontally or vertically.
segment.target: You can orient your slider horizontally or vertically.

segment.source: Use these guidelines to determine which layout to use.
segment.target: Use these guidelines to determine which layout to use.

segment.source: Use a natural orientation.
segment.target: Use a natural orientation.

segment.source: For example, if the slider represents a real-world value that is normally shown vertically (such as temperature), use a vertical orientation.
segment.target: For example, if the slider represents a real-world value that is normally shown vertically (such as temperature), use a vertical orientation.

segment.source: If the control is used to seek within media, like in a video app, use a horizontal orientation.
segment.target: If the control is used to seek within media, like in a video app, use a horizontal orientation.

segment.source: When using a slider in page that can be panned in one direction (horizontally or vertically), use a different orientation for the slider than the panning direction.
segment.target: When using a slider in page that can be panned in one direction (horizontally or vertically), use a different orientation for the slider than the panning direction.

segment.source: Otherwise, users might swipe the slider and change its value accidentally when they try to pan the page.
segment.target: Otherwise, users might swipe the slider and change its value accidentally when they try to pan the page.

segment.source: If you're still not sure which orientation to use, use the one that best fits your page layout.
segment.target: If you're still not sure which orientation to use, use the one that best fits your page layout.

segment.source: Range direction
segment.target: Range direction

segment.source: The range direction is the direction you move the slider when you slide it from its current value to its max value.
segment.target: The range direction is the direction you move the slider when you slide it from its current value to its max value.

segment.source: For vertical slider, put the largest value at the top of the slider, regardless of reading direction.
segment.target: For vertical slider, put the largest value at the top of the slider, regardless of reading direction.

segment.source: For example, for a volume slider, always put the maximum volume setting at the top of the slider.
segment.target: For example, for a volume slider, always put the maximum volume setting at the top of the slider.

segment.source: For other types of values (such as days of the week), follow the reading direction of the page.
segment.target: For other types of values (such as days of the week), follow the reading direction of the page.

segment.source: For horizontal styles, put the lower value on the left side of the slider for left-to-right page layout, and on the right for right-to-left page layout.
segment.target: For horizontal styles, put the lower value on the left side of the slider for left-to-right page layout, and on the right for right-to-left page layout.

segment.source: The one exception to the previous guideline is for media seek bars: always put the lower value on the left side of the slider.
segment.target: The one exception to the previous guideline is for media seek bars: always put the lower value on the left side of the slider.

segment.source: Steps and tick marks
segment.target: Steps and tick marks

segment.source: Use step points if you don't want the slider to allow arbitrary values between min and max. For example, if you use a slider to specify the number of movie tickets to buy, don't allow floating point values.
segment.target: Use step points if you don't want the slider to allow arbitrary values between min and max. For example, if you use a slider to specify the number of movie tickets to buy, don't allow floating point values.

segment.source: Give it a step value of 1.
segment.target: Give it a step value of 1.

segment.source: If you specify steps (also known as snap points), make sure that the final step aligns to the slider's max value.
segment.target: If you specify steps (also known as snap points), make sure that the final step aligns to the slider's max value.

segment.source: Use tick marks when you want to show users the location of major or significant values.
segment.target: Use tick marks when you want to show users the location of major or significant values.

segment.source: For example, a slider that controls a zoom might have tick marks for 50%, 100%, and 200%.
segment.target: For example, a slider that controls a zoom might have tick marks for 50%, 100%, and 200%.

segment.source: Show tick marks when users need to know the approximate value of the setting.
segment.target: Show tick marks when users need to know the approximate value of the setting.

segment.source: Show tick marks and a value label when users need to know the exact value of the setting they choose, without interacting with the control.
segment.target: Show tick marks and a value label when users need to know the exact value of the setting they choose, without interacting with the control.

segment.source: Otherwise, they can use the value tooltip to see the exact value.
segment.target: Otherwise, they can use the value tooltip to see the exact value.

segment.source: Always show tick marks when step points aren't obvious.
segment.target: Always show tick marks when step points aren't obvious.

segment.source: For example, if the slider is 200 pixels wide and has 200 snap points, you can hide the tick marks because users won't notice the snapping behavior.
segment.target: For example, if the slider is 200 pixels wide and has 200 snap points, you can hide the tick marks because users won't notice the snapping behavior.

segment.source: But if there are only 10 snap points, show tick marks.
segment.target: But if there are only 10 snap points, show tick marks.

segment.source: Labels
segment.target: Labels

segment.source: Slider labels
segment.target: Slider labels

segment.source: The slider label indicates what the slider is used for.
segment.target: The slider label indicates what the slider is used for.

segment.source: Use a label with no ending punctuation (this is the convention for all control labels).
segment.target: Use a label with no ending punctuation (this is the convention for all control labels).

segment.source: Position labels above the slider when the slider is in a form that places most of its labels above their controls.
segment.target: Position labels above the slider when the slider is in a form that places most of its labels above their controls.

segment.source: Position labels to the sides when the slider is in a form that places most of its labels to the side of their controls.
segment.target: Position labels to the sides when the slider is in a form that places most of its labels to the side of their controls.

segment.source: Avoid placing labels below the slider because the user's finger might occlude the label when the user touches the slider.
segment.target: Avoid placing labels below the slider because the user's finger might occlude the label when the user touches the slider.

segment.source: Range labels
segment.target: Range labels

segment.source: The range, or fill, labels describe the slider's minimum and maximum values.
segment.target: The range, or fill, labels describe the slider's minimum and maximum values.

segment.source: Label the two ends of the slider range, unless a vertical orientation makes this unnecessary.
segment.target: Label the two ends of the slider range, unless a vertical orientation makes this unnecessary.

segment.source: Use only one word, if possible, for each label.
segment.target: Use only one word, if possible, for each label.

segment.source: Don't use ending punctuation.
segment.target: Don't use ending punctuation.

segment.source: Make sure these labels are descriptive and parallel.
segment.target: Make sure these labels are descriptive and parallel.

segment.source: Examples: Maximum/Minimum, More/Less, Low/High, Soft/Loud.
segment.target: Examples: Maximum/Minimum, More/Less, Low/High, Soft/Loud.

segment.source: Value labels
segment.target: Value labels

segment.source: A value label displays the current value of the slider.
segment.target: A value label displays the current value of the slider.

segment.source: If you need a value label, display it below the slider.
segment.target: If you need a value label, display it below the slider.

segment.source: Center the text relative to the control and include the units (such as pixels).
segment.target: Center the text relative to the control and include the units (such as pixels).

segment.source: Since the slider’s thumb is covered during scrubbing, consider showing the current value some other way, with a label or other visual.
segment.target: Since the slider’s thumb is covered during scrubbing, consider showing the current value some other way, with a label or other visual.

segment.source: A slider setting text size could render some sample text of the right size beside the slider.
segment.target: A slider setting text size could render some sample text of the right size beside the slider.

segment.source: Appearance and interaction
segment.target: Appearance and interaction

segment.source: A slider is composed of a track and a thumb.
segment.target: A slider is composed of a track and a thumb.

segment.source: The track is a bar (which can optionally show various styles of tick marks) representing the range of values that can be input.
segment.target: The track is a bar (which can optionally show various styles of tick marks) representing the range of values that can be input.

segment.source: The thumb is a selector, which the user can position by either tapping the track or by scrubbing back and forth on it.
segment.target: The thumb is a selector, which the user can position by either tapping the track or by scrubbing back and forth on it.

segment.source: A slider has a large touch target.
segment.target: A slider has a large touch target.

segment.source: To maintain touch accessibility, a slider should be positioned far enough away from the edge of the display.
segment.target: To maintain touch accessibility, a slider should be positioned far enough away from the edge of the display.

segment.source: When you’re designing a custom slider, consider ways to present all the necessary info to the user with as little clutter as possible.
segment.target: When you’re designing a custom slider, consider ways to present all the necessary info to the user with as little clutter as possible.

segment.source: Use a value label if a user needs to know the units in order to understand the setting; find creative ways to represent these values graphically.
segment.target: Use a value label if a user needs to know the units in order to understand the setting; find creative ways to represent these values graphically.

segment.source: A slider that controls volume, for example, could display a speaker graphic without sound waves at the minimum end of the slider, and a speaker graphic with sound waves at the maximum end.
segment.target: A slider that controls volume, for example, could display a speaker graphic without sound waves at the minimum end of the slider, and a speaker graphic with sound waves at the maximum end.
